Hmm, I remember that each predator has an efficiency rate, meaning they convert a certain percentage of their body mass into kinetic energy or other forms. So for example, if a mouse eats clover with 50% efficiency, it takes out half its body weight as energy. The ten percent rule probably means that each level of consumption (from prey to predator) reduces the available energy by a factor of 10. So starting from the prey, each subsequent level loses another tenth. Let me outline the steps: 1. Clover → Mice: Efficiency = 10%
   So the mouse consumes 10% of the clover's energy. That leaves 90% of the clover's energy remaining after the mouse eats. 2. Mice → Skunks: Efficiency = 10%
   Now, the skunk eats 10% of what the mouse ate. But since the mouse already took 10%, we're dealing with 10% of the mouse's intake. Wait, no—actually, each level applies the 10%.
